observed.content:
The RECORD statement – checklist of items, extended from the STROBE statement, that should be reported in observational studies using 
routinely collected health data. 
 
 Item 
No. 
STROBE items Location in 
manuscript where 
items are reported 
RECORD items Location in 
manuscript 
where items are 
reported 
Title and abstract  
 1 (a) Indicate the study’s design 
with a commonly used term in 
the title or the abstract (b) 
Provide in the abstract an 
informative and balanced 
summary of what was done and 
what was found 
 RECORD 1.1: The type of data used 
should be specified in the title or 
abstract. When possible, the name of 
the databases used should be included. 
 
RECORD 1.2: If applicable, the 
geographic region and timeframe 
within which the study took place 
should be reported in the title or 
abstract. 
 
RECORD 1.3: If linkage between 
databases was conducted for the study, 
this should be clearly stated in the title 
or abstract. 
 
Introduction 
Background 
rationale

prompts.text:
Based on the following context from a biomedical paper:

The RECORD statement – checklist of items, extended from the STROBE statement, that should be reported in observational studies using 
routinely collected health data. 
 
 Item 
No. 
STROBE items Location in 
manuscript where 
items are reported 
RECORD items Location in 
manuscript 
where items are 
reported 
Title and abstract  
 1 (a) Indicate the study’s design 
with a commonly used term in 
the title or the abstract (b) 
Provide in the abstract an 
informative and balanced 
summary of what was done and 
what was found 
 RECORD 1.1: The type of data used 
should be specified in the title or 
abstract. When possible, the name of 
the databases used should be included. 
 
RECORD 1.2: If applicable, the 
geographic region and timeframe 
within which the study took place 
should be reported in the title or 
abstract. 
 
RECORD 1.3: If linkage between 
databases was conducted for the study, 
this should be clearly stated in the title 
or abstract. 
 
Introduction 
Background 
rationale

Please analyze the text and identify how it addresses each of the following RECORD checklist items:

1. Title and Abstract Analysis:
- Is the type of data used specified? Are database names included?
- Is the geographic region and timeframe reported?
- If applicable, is database linkage clearly stated?

2. Methods Analysis:
- Are the population selection methods (codes/algorithms) detailed?
- Are validation studies of selection methods referenced?
- For linked databases, is there a clear data linkage process?
- Are all classification codes and algorithms listed?

3. Data Handling:
- Is the extent of database access described?
- Are data cleaning methods explained?
- For linked data, are linkage methods and quality evaluation provided?

4. Results and Limitations:
- Is the selection of included persons described in detail?
- Are the implications of using routine data discussed?

5. Accessibility:
- Is information provided on accessing supplemental materials?

For each item, provide:
1. Whether it is addressed (Yes/No/Partially)
2. The relevant text from the paper
3. Any gaps or recommendations for improvement
prompts.system_prompt: You are an expert in observational study, please based on {checklist_content} create prompts that can be used in LLMs to generate the checlist based on biomedical papers, for example RECORD 1.1: The type of data used should be specified in the title or abstract. When possible, the name of the databases used should be included.

title_abstract: RECORD 1.1: Data type and database names in title/abstract
RECORD 1.2: Geographic region and timeframe in title/abstract
RECORD 1.3: Database linkage statement in title/abstract
participants: RECORD 6.2: Validation studies of selection codes/algorithms
RECORD 6.3: Data linkage process and flow diagram
variables: RECORD 7.1: Complete list of classification codes and algorithms
data_methods: RECORD 12.3: Database linkage details and quality evaluation
results: RECORD 13.1: Detailed selection of included persons
limitations: RECORD 19.1: Implications of using routine data
